keyTakeAways: A Slovak court found Juraj Cintula guilty of terrorism charges in connection with an attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024.
Cintula, a 72-year-old former mine worker and public activist, shot Fico five times during a public greeting in Handlova, leaving Fico seriously injured.
The Specialized Criminal Court in Banska Bystrica ruled that the attack was politically motivated and specifically targeted the prime minister, qualifying as terrorism under Slovak law.
Cintula claimed he wanted to stop Fico's policies, which he said damaged Slovak freedom and culture, and stated he did not intend to kill.
The court acknowledged Cintula's stated motive but still classified the act as terrorism due to its targeted nature and political implications.
The verdict sparked national debates over political violence, democratic erosion, and the role of populist leadership in fueling societal divisions.
Fico, who has been in power since 2006, blames opposition parties for fostering anger, while opposition leaders accuse him of undermining media freedom and democratic norms.
Cintula stated he would appeal the sentence, calling it 'unjust,' and his defense argued that not all attacks on officials constitute terrorism.
Fico has publicly forgiven Cintula, despite ongoing health complications from the attack.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Slovak court sentenced 72-year-old Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison for attempting to assassinate Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024 during a public event in Handlova. The attack, which wounded Fico severely, was classified as terrorism by the Specialized Criminal Court in Banska Bystrica, based on the targeted nature of the act and Cintula's stated opposition to Fico's policies on Ukraine, media, and culture. Cintula, a former mine worker and public activist, claimed he did not intend to kill, but the court found that the attack constituted a terrorist act due to its political intent. The verdict intensified national debates over political polarization, democratic standards, and the role of populist leadership. Fico, who returned to power in 2023, has faced criticism for policies perceived as undermining freedoms, while opposition groups accuse him of eroding democratic norms. Despite the conviction, Cintula expressed intent to appeal, and Fico has publicly forgiven the suspect, underscoring the complex emotional and political aftermath of the incident.
title: Slovakia court sentences suspect in attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico to 21 years
